```{r}
#Delete unnecessary rows to do normalization test and modelling test
cleanSASFilter<-cleanSAS[!(cleanSAS$State=="united states" | cleanSAS$State=="united states total" | cleanSAS$Sex=="male total" | cleanSAS$Sex=="female total" | cleanSAS$Sex=="all sexes"),]
nrow(cleanSASFilter)
cleanSASFilter<-as.data.frame(cleanSASFilter,dec = ".", stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
cleanSASFilter
cleanSASFilter$State<-as.factor(cleanSASFilter$State)
cleanSASFilter$Sex<-as.factor(cleanSASFilter$Sex)
cleanSASFilter$Age.group<-as.factor(cleanSASFilter$Age.group)
str(cleanSASFilter)
par("mar")
par(mar=c(1,1,1,1))
par(mfrow=c(5,2))

#The data COVID.19.Deaths is normal if the p-value is above 0.05.But p-value < 2.2e-16, it is not normal distributed
shapiro.test(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths)
hCOVID<-hist(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths,breaks=500, col="blue",freq=FALSE)
#Fit a curve to a historgram
dCOVID<-density(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths, cut = 0)
lines(dCOVID, col = 2)
# Fit a normal curve to a histogram because it is not normally distributed
hCOVIDnew<-hist(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths,breaks=100, col="blue",freq=TRUE)
hCOVIDnew
xfit<-seq(min(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths),max(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths),length=400) 
yfit<-dnorm(xfit,mean=mean(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths),sd=sd(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths)) 
yfit <- yfit*diff(hCOVIDnew$mids[1:2])*length(cleanSASFilter$COVID.19.Deaths) 
lines(xfit, yfit, col="red", lwd=2) 


#The data Pneumonia.Deaths is normal if the p-value is above 0.05.But p-value < 2.2e-16, it is not normal distributed
```

```{r}
#The reason behind applying non-parametric test and what are the assumptions of applying such test: data not normaly distributed and sample size is small
#Because the data are not normally distributed so We are going to apply non-parametric measure to do the modelling to predict the results

KcleanSASUSAO

#Apply non-paired 2 group wilcox rank test.p-value = 0.05379> significance level alpha = 0.050. We can conclude that whole USA's female's death does NOT significantly different than male's death with a p-value = 0.05379.

#Conclusion: USA's female's death does NOT significantly different from male's death with a p-value = 0.054.Both sexes have same distribution of datas. We can also inference that both sexes have same significant affect to COVID-19 DEATHS.
```

```{r}
KcleanSASUSAW
KcleanSASUSAW$`under 1 year`

mergedKcleanSASUSAW
#each group has non-identical medians and means.
Summarize(COVID.19.Deaths~ Age.group,data = mergedKcleanSASUSAW) 
histogram(~ COVID.19.Deaths| Age.group, data=mergedKcleanSASUSAW,layout=c(1,1))
boxplot(COVID.19.Deaths ~ Age.group,data = mergedKcleanSASUSAW,ylab="COVID.19.Deaths",xlab="Age.group")
#As the p-value< 2.2e-16 is less than the significance level 0.05, we can conclude that there are significant differences distributions between the treatments of age groups.
#From the output of the Kruskal-Wallis test, we know that there is a significant difference between age groups, but we don’t know which pairs of age groups are different. Therefore, we are going to apply post-hoc tests
mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group<-as.factor(mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group)
kruskal.test(mergedKcleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths ~ mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group, data = mergedKcleanSASUSAW)
#Dunn test is appropriate for groups with unequal numbers of observations:
PTD = dunnTest(COVID.19.Deaths ~ Age.group,data=mergedKcleanSASUSAW,method="bh")
PTD
PTD = PTD$res
PTD
#We get result of do have significant differences.
#cldList(comparison = PTD$Comparison,p.value= PTD$P.adj,threshold  = 0.05)
#Nemenyi test is appropriate for groups with equal numbers of observations:We get result of having significant differences
PTN = NemenyiTest(x = mergedKcleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Death,g = mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group,dist="tukey")
PTN
#We get result of do have significant differences.
#cldList(comparison = PTN$Comparison,p.value = PTN$P.adj,threshold  = 0.05)
#Mann–Whitney U-tests.To prevent the inflation of type I error rates, adjustments to the p-values can be made using the p.adjust.method option to control the familywise error rate or to control the false discovery rate
PTP =pairwise.wilcox.test(mergedKcleanSASUSAW$COVID.19.Deaths, mergedKcleanSASUSAW$Age.group, p.adjust.method = "none")
PTP 
PTP = PTP$p.value
PTP
PTP1 = fullPTable(PTP)
PTP1
#Values sharing the same letter are not significantly different: We get All group ranges do have significant differences
ComLetter<-multcompLetters(PTP1, compare="<", threshold=0.05,Letters=letters,reversed = FALSE)
ComLetter
```

```{r}
#Logistic Regression/binary logistic regression/binomial logistic regression/logit model.It is used to model a binary outcome, that is a variable, which can have only two possible values: 0 or 1. P is the probability of event to occur "1" given by x. P(event=1|x). P/(1-P) = exp(b0 + b1*x). log[P/(1-P)] = b0 + b1*x1 + b2*x2 + ... + bn*xn. P(event=1|x)= 1/[1 + exp(-(b0 + b1*x))]. A positive b1 indicates that increasing x will be associated with increasing p. Conversely, a negative b1 indicates that increasing x will be associated with decreasing P. The odds reflect the likelihood that the event will occur. It can be seen as the ratio of “successes” to “non-successes”. Technically, odds are the probability of an event divided by the probability that the event will not take place. P = Odds/(1 + Odds). Odds=P/(1-P). If the odds ratio is 2, then the odds that the event occurs (event = 1) are two times higher when the predictor x is present (x = 1) versus x is absent (x = 0). Association Rules: Unsupervised Classification Method
```
```{r}
# We create transactions. We convert each column into a factor or a logical to ensure that the column takes values only from a fixed set.
cleanSASFilterA<-cleanSAS[!(cleanSAS$State=="united states" | cleanSAS$State=="united states total" | cleanSAS$Sex=="male total" | cleanSAS$Sex=="female total" | cleanSAS$Sex=="all sexes"),]
nrow(cleanSASFilterA)
cleanSASFilterA<-data.frame(cleanSASFilterA, stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
cleanSASFilterA$State<-as.factor(cleanSASFilterA$State)
cleanSASFilterA$Sex<-as.factor(cleanSASFilterA$Sex)
cleanSASFilterA$Age.group<-as.factor(cleanSASFilterA$Age.group)
#We divide all the numerical variables AS 4 factorial variables
cleanSASFilterA$COVID.19.Deaths <- quantcut(cleanSASFilterA$COVID.19.Deaths, 4)
cleanSASFilterA$Pneumonia.Deaths<-quantcut(cleanSASFilterA$Pneumonia.Deaths, 4)
cleanSASFilterA$Pneumonia.and.COVID.19.Deaths <-quantcut(cleanSASFilterA$Pneumonia.and.COVID.19.Deaths, 4)
cleanSASFilterA$Influenza.Deaths<-quantcut(cleanSASFilterA$Influenza.Deaths, 4)
cleanSASFilterA$Pneumonia..Influenza..or.COVID.19.Deaths<-quantcut(cleanSASFilterA$Pneumonia..Influenza..or.COVID.19.Deaths, 4)
str(cleanSASFilterA)
summary(cleanSASFilterA)
par("mar")
par(mar=c(1,1,1,1))
View(cleanSASFilterA)
# Finding association rules: Support : % cases that include both "if" and "then" items. Confidence: % cases that with "if" also have "then" items. Lift: confidence (% cases with "then" items)
# 256 rule(s
rules1<-apriori(cleanSASFilterA)
summary(rules1)
rules1<-sort(rules1, by="confidence", decreasing=TRUE) 
rules1<-sort(rules1, by="lift", decreasing=TRUE)
inspect(rules1)
# Reduce to smaller number of rules
rules2<-apriori(cleanSASFilterA, parameter=list(minlen=2, maxlen=6, supp=0.2))
summary(rules2)
inspect(rules2)
# Finding interesting rules - 1 
rules3<-apriori(cleanSASFilterA, parameter=list(minlen=2, maxlen=6, supp=0.2),appearance=list(rhs=c("COVID.19.Deaths=(29,2.9]"), default="lhs"))
inspect(rules3)
# Visualizing Rules
plot(rules3)
plot(rules3, method="grouped")
plot(rules3, method="graph", control=list(type="items"))
# Finding interesting rules - 2
rules4<-apriori(cleanSASFilterA, parameter=list(minlen=2, maxlen=6, supp=0.2, conf=0.5),appearance=list(rhs=c("COVID.19.Deaths=(29,2.9]"), lhs=c("State=new york city", "Sex=male","Pneumonia.and.COVID.19.Deaths=(12,1.14]","Pneumonia..Influenza..or.COVID.19.Deaths=(86,3.17e+03]","Pneumonia.Deaths=(60,1.68]","Influenza.Deaths=(4.12,145]", "Age.group=85 years and over"), default="none"))
quality(rules4)<-round(quality(rules4), digits = 3)
inspect(rules4)
```
